title: Don't shove your lane and complain about being ganked/not receiving ganks
body: By shoving you not only make it harder for your jungler to gank you make it way easier for the enemy to gank. Especially if you don't ward at all. 75 Gold is worth it if it means not dying and giving the enemy 300+ gold.

Snipped the rest for brevity, since this is basically the important part.

I prefer jungle myself, and let me tell you, *it is extremely hard to set up a counter-gank.*

You need to have wards that warn you well in advance of the enemy jungler (or laner) ganking, and there are multiple paths they can take for it. On top of that, you need to be in the same quarter of the map if you want to be able to respond quickly enough. If you're more than 10 seconds away, you might not even make it there before the whole thing is over.

Counter-ganking is less of a strategy and more of a reaction. It *is* a strategic reaction, but you can't really plan for it. Back in the older seasons when there was no ward limit, you could get enough vision to plan it out, but that's ancient history.

> [{quoted}](name=FlyingGünther,realm=EUW,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=Ue0oRgfF,comment-id=000000000000,timestamp=2015-05-03T21:29:26.567+0000)

1) I'm a jungler, not a psychic. I'm going to place wards--and *hopefully* the laners will as well--in locations where I can see the enemy players coming in, so we can intercept them or avoid them. That doesn't mean I'm going to know where the enemy jungler is at all times. I might see them once in a while when they try to do a thing where I've warded, but that's as much as everyone else will know.

2) Yes, it *is* a reaction. The only way counter-ganking can not be a fully reactive play is if you are **camping the lane.** Which means losing gold and exp to babysit a lane that's pushed, but doesn't want you walking close enough to get exp or farm gold (and I'm not an asshole; laners need their gold and exp just as much, so I'm not going to drain them if they're there). While I have no problem with taking 30 seconds to stand on the sidelines as a human ward, if I wait too long for something to happen, all I'll have done is given the enemy jungler an easy lead--or worse, an opening to take objectives or gank another lane while I was protecting one lane--because I'm not farming anything.

I don't know your ELO, but I know you know *nothing* about jungling.

So I think the guy you're responding to is wrong too, but as someone who mained jg s3, and plays a champ that is almost always pushed top lane now I can comment a little as to areas where you're a bit off too.

So the thing about maining jungle is you know jungle pathing and thinking better than most other players. While you aren't psychic and can't know where the jungle is at all times, you can predict what they want to do to some degree and if you have wards in their jungle you can guess where they are a decent amount of time by where they are not. I play nunu jungle and if I generally start bot side and ward their gromp/krugs at around 55 or 60 seconds so I can see if the enemy jungle starts bot. If they don't I KNOW they started top and I can steal there buff for free 90% of the time. If you have their chickens warded and haven't seen them there in a while plus your bot lane is perma pushed, drop a ward bot river and go take krugs bc the enemy is probably ganking bot soon (it's what I'd be doing if I wasn't top side and bot lane was pushed by the enemy, so I figure it's probably what they want to do too).

Similarly, while I'm pissed if my jungle is sitting in the bushes waiting on my sidelines leaching exp from me and not getting any gold when they could be farming, if our other lanes are both keeping even but are pushed in and I'm auto attacking the enemy tower top, I'm probably getting ganked soon. Come farm your top side jungle and when you see the enemy cross my ward head to top lane and let's bait them into a fight they'll lose. Side note this only works if I have a ward and if I don't it is not on you to counter gank.

Basically as jungle it's not your job to save me if I'm playing bad, but if I tell you I'm gonna be pushed and we can tower dive at level six in 30 sec come top. If you know you would want to gank me as the enemy jungle and there are no other lanes that look good if you were the enemy then assume they're coming top and either throw down a ward for me (if mine timed out and I haven't had a chance to go back yet), or farm your top side jungle and be ready to counter gank. It isn't always perfect, but if you play that way you'll see your ability to counter gank go WAY up and it definitely is not purely reactionary.

Yes, I have an *idea* of what they might do, if they're following a normal jungle path. And, in the level of play where people aren't meta-breaking, that's totally reasonable.

Also, that last paragraph's first sentence pretty much highlights the core of jungling.

I'm not as good at it as I used to be but in s3 it seemed like the biggest difference between bronze, silver, and gold (I didn't work hard enough to get past low gold really) was how accurate enemies (and myself as I climbed since I got better at it) predicted the other jungle's movements based on champ and what they probably wanted to do. It is part of how you shut down the enemy jungle, and maybe you have success with a different play style, but in my experience shutting down the other jungle works better for me than playing an arms race to see who can get their self and their lanes ahead the most while letting the enemy do the same.

As you reach higher levels, people *also* know what's expected of the class, as well as what they can do that is not expected, but still close to (if not equally) optimal.

It's actually not that hard to do at my ELO. If you know what's expected of you, and if you know an equally strong but different strategy, they won't have the right reaction to the playstyle shift. That small offset puts the advantage in your favor.
> The only constant between your games is you. You also don't get to plat off 11/6 alone, he's been playing at a plat rank or above for more than one season.

Yes, the only constant in your own game history is yourself. Not your opponents or your teammates, but you. *However,* this game is quite literally designed to be impossible for one player to be the sole reason a team wins at his level of play (or even mine). What separates good and great players is teamwork.

Also, I'm not calling into question him hitting Plat period. Although I'm sick of players trying to use "You're unranked!" as an argument, because that has nothing to do with how much I've learned over four years of playing the game, the only thing I called into question is his jungle play. The record I pulled up was missing information, and he corrected me on that. He doesn't have a terrible record as a jungler, just what could be called acceptable when you consider what's expected at his level of play.

>As you reach higher levels, people also know what's expected of the class, as well as what they can do that is not expected, but still close to (if not equally) optimal.

>It's actually not that hard to do at my ELO. If you know what's expected of you, and if you know an equally strong but different strategy, they won't have the right reaction to the playstyle shift. That small offset puts the advantage in your favor.

It's more of a shift to awareness to timers at higher levels than anything else. When you get to higher levels people start doing things like shifting clear patterns to secure buffs.

An example of how you can use this is to ward their first botside buff to try to get the timer for it. You could then utilise that timer to do a few things. You can gank top on the timer assuming there's no dragon pressure as you know they'll most likely be in their bot side jungle. You can use the timing when they move up towards their top side buff to attempt to rush a Drag. Or you could hang around bot side to make sure you're ready to countergank if their jungle does gank.

But the thing with all these strategies is that the only work if the enemy is actually doing what you expect. At higher ranks there's a very good chance they will be but down in lower ranks there's a much higher chance that the enemy jungle is doing their doubles completely oblivious to the fact that their blue just spawned.

>Yes, the only constant in your own game history is yourself. Not your opponents or your teammates, but you. However, this game is quite literally designed to be impossible for one player to be the sole reason a team wins at his level of play (or even mine). What separates good and great players is teamwork.

I didn't call your rank into question. I just said that it's silly to dismiss his rank off of solely having good team-mates. I also never said that I believe his rank holds greater sway than yours at all, you're just reading that into what I wrote.

And the thing about knowing what's expected is that you can plan around it. You can either bait them into following their plan in a way that your team can capitalize, or you can force them to change their plan because you don't make it easy/possible to execute it.

I'm not talking about when players do the unexpected because they aren't aware of the Path of Least Resistance (aka optimal route, meta, best playstyle, etc.). I'm talking about players who are aware of the meta, and meta-play around the meta because their opponents are expecting the meta.
